results.title: Ordinary decent criminal
results.creator_credit: Thaddeus O'Sullivan, Jonathan Cavendish, ICON and Little Bird
results.brief_description: Kevin Spacey plays Michael Lynch, a suave and cocky Irish gangster who has something of a reputation with ordinary folk as a local hero. With a loyal gang and always two steps ahead of the law, Michael plans numerous heists, such as a daylight robbery of a precious Caravaggio, along with pulling ordinary bank jobs and robbing his own dole office. Michael’s unusual home life consists of two partners, who are sisters, and numerous children, a delightful arrangement for one and all. Enraged by Michael’s elusiveness and brazen disregard for authority, the police place him and his lot under unyielding surveillance, but the scallywag gives them the slip every time. “Ordinary decent criminal” is a reworking of the true to life Martin Cahill story as told in “The General” (John Boorman, 1998), a far more cynical film about crime. O’Sullivan’s film has a certain incongruity in tone - it is mostly jaunty with a hip soundtrack, but occasionally cuts to violent encounters. Spacey depicts Lynch as a clever, vain and loveable rouge with a wry smile, but a thief and swindler at heart.

results.title: Two women = Do zan [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Arman Film and Arta Film
results.brief_description: Two women, Fereshteh (Niki Karimi) and Roya (Marila Zare’i) become friends while studying at Tehran University. There’s a cloud of doubt over whether the university will stay open however, there’s rioting, and Fereshteh fears her future plans to become educated and enlightened will not eventuate. One day she is approached by a girl at university who wants to introduce her to Ahmad, a potential husband, she’s also being harassed by a man who follows her around campus and insists he is in love with her. One day the man sees her with her cousin and, believing him to be her lover, throws acid on him. Fereshteh is unfairly blamed for the incident and her father demands she leave university and return home. An unfortunate accident removes her harasser when he is sent to jail, but Fereshteh is held to blame also and is bailed out by Ahmad, her life and family honour indebted to him due to his financial assistance. Milani’s fifth film is an accomplished piece about a woman stifled in her attempt at liberation by a trinity involving her father, her husband, and a stranger.

results.title: The Hidden half = Nimeh-ye penhan [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Mohammad Nikbin, Arta Film and Iranian Film Society
results.brief_description: The dutiful wife of an Iranian judge uses her husband’s impending case of a woman facing execution for an unspecified crime to reveal the truth of her past revolutionary activities and to illustrate that the stories of people must be heard before passing judgement. Using the device of a diary and an extended flashback, Fereshteh (Niki Karima, Best Actress, Cairo International Film Festival) explains how her life changed drastically when she went to university, joined the Communist party, then fell in love with a married man. Feminist director Tahmineh Milani was imprisoned by the Islamic Revolutionary Court following the film’s release and is on parole; the film was also pulled from Tehran screens after a month but later returned. Melodramatic at times, the film’s history overshadows its content yet still manages to convey the oppression of Iranian women under an Islamic regime in pre and post revolutionary Iran. In Farsi with English subtitles. Please note: the white subtitles are sometimes hard to read on screen.

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: The Music box. Busy bodies. Towed in a hole
results.creator_credit: George Marshall, James Parrott, Lloyd French, Hal Roach, Hal Roach Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Three short films from classic slapstick comedy duo Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. “The Music Box” - Stan and Ollie are deliverymen whose task is to deliver a valuable piano to an irascible professor. The pair struggles with the piano up and down a daunting set of concrete stairs, causing a slew of unmitigated disasters once finally inside the house. This short film was honoured with an Oscar for “Best Live-Action Short Subject.” “Busy bodies” - short film brimming with sight gags, sees Laurel and Hardy driving to work in an old jalopy causing mayhem, distracting others with a gramophone hooked up under the bonnet. Once at work, the havoc continues as they irritate the foreman and cause non-stop harm to one another. Some of the gags recall the complex set-ups of Bester Keaton’s finest work. “Towed in a hole” - short that ably illustrates the comic chemistry between the two stars. Laurel and Hardy are successful fish salesmen; Stan decides they can increase their profit by cutting out the middleman and catching their own fish off the jetty. Ollie one-ups him by buying a holey boat, over which the two bicker like children, in their attempt to repair it. Immensely funny physical and inspired comedy.

results.title: When we were kings [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Leon Gast, Taylor Hackford, David Sonenberg and DAS Films
results.brief_description: The heavyweight title fight between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman in Kinshasa (Zaire) on 30 October 1974 - `The Rumble in the Jungle’ - is enshrined as one of the great sports events of the century. It was also a cultural and political happening. Utilizing original footage of the fight, the film is on one level a lost documentary revealing never-before-seen images of the Fight of the Century between a then relatively unpopular, but fearsome, boxer named George Foreman and his nearly mythical antagonist, the incomparable Muhammad Ali. Filmmakers Gast and Hackford also construct a riveting story of the drama and significance of an event which signified the beginning of a new age of black culture and identity. Complete with performances by B.B. King, James Brown, and Miriam Makeba, marked by the launching of the career of notorious promoter Don King, and overshadowed by the ominous presence of Zaire’s President Mobutu, this is a discourse on what it meant to be black in America in that tumultuous time. Not only does the film deal with issues of segregation and integration and the emergence of black pride and black consciousness, but most critically, it describes the return to Africa of black American visitors. At the centre of the film is Ali, who, both as athlete and entertainer, persona and man, is a compelling figure, deeply committed to issues of racial, religious and political justice. The film also features insights and commentary from Norman Mailer, George Plimpton, and Spike Lee.

results.title: Casino [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on material gathered for a non-fiction book by Nicholas Pileggi, “Casino” takes an in depth look at the behind the scenes world of a casino whilst following the history of the mob in Las Vegas. It is 1973 and Sam Rothstein (Robert de Niro) is sent by the mob to manage the Tangiers casino. Sam’s childhood friend Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci), follows him to Vegas whereupon he’s hired to enforce mob control. Sam’s successful running of the Tangiers is soon jeopardised by Nicky’s hotheaded thuggery and the explosive behaviour of his coke-addicted wife Ginger (Sharon Stone). “Casino” is Martin Scorsese’s tribute to a Las Vegas now gone. The film is marked with Scorsese’s usual visual flair and kinetic style, with a deadpan voiceover narration from Sam and occasionally Nicky. Sharon Stone gives a knockout performance as the unstable Ginger.

results.title: Apocalypse now: redux [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola and Omni Zoetrope
results.brief_description: A stunning vision of man’s heart of darkness, revealed through the particular madness of the Vietnam War. Lieutenant Willard receives orders to seek out the renegade Colonel Kurtz, who has disappeared into the depths of the jungle. Willard’s mission becomes an epic journey into his own soul and that of the mysterious Kurtz. The trails of making this film are well documented, particularly within “Hearts of darkness: a filmmaker’s apocalypse” (1991) - Coppola’s financial, casting and location woes complicated his desire to deliver an anti-war work that would find an audience. In 2000 he began working on restoring key scenes, deleted in 1979, identifying those that expounded upon his themes of military madness and moral degradation. New scenes include: Willard’s seduction by a widow after attending a dinner at the home of a French plantation owner, the sumptuousness of which speaks of yearning for an idealised past and reflects Willard’s retreat from the present; the Playboy bunnies become stranded and Willard’s crew offer them fuel in exchange for sex, compounding the sense of the military’s ethical deprivation; Kurtz extrapolates upon the insanity of war, a philosophical scene linked to the denouement. Coppola’s original work won numerous accolades, but many critics questioned the rationale behind “Redux” and theorised that it perhaps reflected his failure to produce engaging work throughout the 1990s.

results.title: Scarface [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Martin Bregman and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: In Brian DePalma’s 1983 adaptation of “Scarface”, Al Pacino stars as Tony Montana, an exiled Cuban criminal who lands in Miami after Castro opened Mariel Harbour in 1980. Montana goes to work for a Miami drug lord (Robert Loggia), but soon rises to the top of Florida’s crime chain, appropriating Loggia’s coke-head mistress (Michelle Pfeiffer) in the process. Once having created a cocaine empire, Montana sees it crumbling at the edges as he descends into drug-induced paranoia, destroying all those who are close to him, and eventually himself. Features screenplay by Oliver Stone and music by Giorgio Moroder. Cast includes: Al Pacino, Steven Bauer, Michelle Pfeiffer, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Robert Loggia.

Once having created a cocaine empire, Montana sees it crumbling at the edges as he descends into drug-induced paranoia, destroying all those who are close to him, and eventually himself. Features screenplay by Oliver Stone and music by Giorgio Moroder. Cast includes: Al Pacino, Steven Bauer, Michelle Pfeiffer, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Robert Loggia.

results.title: What dreams may come
results.creator_credit: Vincent Ward, Barnet Bain, Stephen Simon, Interscope communications, Metafilmics and PolyGram Filmed Entertainment
results.brief_description: Annie (a painting conservator) and Chris (a paediatrician) barely recover after the tragic loss of their two children when Chris is fatally wounded in a car accident. Shortly afterwards he experiences life on the ‘other side’, aided by Albert (Cuba Gooding Jr), a spiritual guide who steers Chris through the psychological impediments that hinder acceptance of his death. When Annie commits suicide and goes to hell, Chris follows, risking his own eternal presence in heaven, to save her. “What dreams may come” won an Academy Award for its special effects but most critics found the film too preternaturally mawkish and sentimental to be taken seriously as a work that ponders the portentous issues of metaphysics and spirituality. Heaven is depicted as Impressionist paintings come to life; Hell is a vision akin to the horrific Gothic vision of Hieronymus Bosch. But impressive as the film’s aesthetics are, an over-reliance, indeed emphasis, on computer generated wizardry, robs it of any dramaturgical import. Additionally its over-determination to reunite the nuclear family stultifies any dramatic intentions and demands inordinate absurdity from the narrative.

results.title: The Adventures of Rocky & Bullwinkle
results.creator_credit: Des McAnuff, Jane Rosenthal, Robert De Niro, Dritte Beteiligung KC Median AG and Co and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: 35 years after the cancellation of the successful cartoon show “Rocky & Bullwinkle” and there is a plea for them to save the world when evil cold war cohorts Fearless Leader (Robert De Niro), Boris (Jason Alexander) and Natasha (Rene Russo) find a way of making it from being an animated character to a real one. Fearless Leader plans to buy up as much cable television time as possible for their program RBTV (really bad television) and feed mindless drivel to the masses, turn them into zombies, and provide malleable intellects to support his plans for being president. FBI agent Karen Sympathy (Piper Perabo) brings the moose and the squirrel back into the real world and takes a road trip with her cartoon heroes in pursuit of Fearless Leader. An impressive blend of animation and live action, the cast also includes Randy Quaid and features cameos by John Goodman, Billy Crystal and Whoopi Goldberg. Pitched at both adults and children, there are sight gags and corny puns as well as plenty of irony for those that can notice. Written by Kenneth Lonergan and based on characters developed by Jay Ward.
